awd_titl_txt: Global Existence and Computer-Assisted Proofs of Singularities in Incompressible Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
The dynamics of free surfaces moving with incompressible fluids occurs in many problems in engineering and science. For short times, the behaviour of solutions is understood in many cases. However, the theory of existence (or not) of singularities, and long term behavior of solutions, is far from well-developed. An example of singularities are the breaking of waves, the formation of a tornado or the splash of a drop.

This project takes two directions: on the one hand it addresses the fundamental question of whether there exists breakdown of smooth solutions in finite time, paying particular attention to the type of breakdown and to the quantity that blows up and on the other the existence of global solutions that exist for all time. Two equations are considered: the generalized surface quasi-geostrophic (gSQG) equation- both in the smooth and the patch case -, a family of models which interpolates between the surface quasi-geostrophic (SQG) equation and the Euler vorticity equation; and the two dimensional free boundary Euler equations. In order to carry out the project, a combination of techniques among an interdisciplinary tool set is required. These include, but are not restricted to, mathematical analysis, high-performance numerical computing, and rigorous computations leading to computer-assisted proofs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant had two equally important components. On the scientific side we focused on several problems concerning the dynamics of fluids, such as long-term regularity of solutions and formation of singularities. On the broader impact side the PIs (Gomez-Serrano and Ionescu) continued collaborations with several researchers at other mathematical centers in the US, and mentored several young students and postdoctoral researchers.

 

The main scientific results of the PIs concern theorems in Fluid Dynamics (rigidity and flexibility results for the Euler, SQG and vortex sheet equations) as well as in Spectral Geometry (isospectrality results for polygons). These represent important steps in understanding fundamental questions such as global existence or formation of singularities for hydrodynamic equations, as well as being able to determine a domain given its spectrum (popularly known as ``hearing the shape of a drum'').

 

The PIs have been very actively involved in the training and mentoring of postdoctoral scholars (J. Park - Universitat de Barcelona), graduate students (J. Shi - Princeton University), as well as undergraduate students who are now graduate students (G. Orriols - now at ETH -, G. Cao - now at MIT -, K. Hou - still an undergraduate at Princeton -, R. Arbon - now at UCLA -, M. Mannan - now at NYU -, M. Psenka - now at Stanford -, S. Ragavan - now at Citadel Securities but applying for Graduate School) even developing an exchange program bringing the most talented students from Spain to the US, some of them staying to pursue Graduate studies. It is important to remark that all of the aforementioned students wrote at least one paper published in serious mathematical journals. In addition the PIs delivered lectures and minicourses for the general mathematical audience and integrated part of the material as part of advanced courses at Princeton and Brown.


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Alexandru D Ionescu
